metadata.name: Gaia DR3 default
metadata.description: Good balance between good distances and number of stars. Contains stars with up to 20%/1.5% bright/faint parallax relative error.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 small
metadata.description: The very best stars in DR3, those with up to 10%/0.5% bright/faint parallax relative error.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 medium
metadata.description: Contains a moderate number of stars, with up to 30%/5% bright/faint parallax relative error.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 large
metadata.description: Contains a large number of stars, with up to 50%/12.5% bright/faint parallax relative error.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.description: Contains a very large number of stars, with up to 50% parallax relative error.

- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 extra large
metadata.description: Contains an extremely large number of stars, with up to 95% parallax relative error.

- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 bright
metadata.description: Contains most of the brightest stars in DR3, those with up to 90%/1% bright/faint parallax relative error.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 RUWE
metadata.description: Stars for which the RUWE (re-normalized unit weight error) is <= 1.4.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Parallaxes are using the corrected terms.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 bayesian distances
metadata.description: Contains all stars with bayesian distances as determined by Bailer-Jones et. al.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are from Bayler-Jones et.al.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 fidelity
metadata.description: Stars for which the fidelity value is > 0.5.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are derived from parallaxes (d=1000/plx).
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.

metadata.name: Gaia DR3 photometric distances
metadata.description: All stars with photometric distances from GSP-Phot Aeneas best library using BP/RP spectra.
metadata.releasenotes:
- Contains Hipparcos stars.
- The cross-match table used is in the archive.
- Distances are from the distance_gspphot column in the archive.
- Extinction and reddening terms are applied to magnitudes and colors.
